div1.p: Fricks reports on the progress of the malaria campaign in the southern United States.

div1.head: Report: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, August 6, 1924
div1.opener:
The File
Malaria
Reports.
FB
August 6, 1924.
Monthly Progress Report,
July 1924.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress
report of malaria investigations conducted during the month
of July, 1924, under the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: - Personnel- Special
Expert M. A. Barber, Assoc. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp and Tech-
nical Assistant Theo. B. Hayne.

Activities of this laboratory consisted of: (1) Preparation
of a paper for the International Conference on Health Prob-
lems in Tropical America, to be read at Kingston, Jamaica;
(2) Tests on mosquito repellents for personal protection in
the open and creosote in dwellings; (3) Tests of various lar-
vicides; (4) Study of the nutrition of Anopheles; (5) Observ-
ations on the production of Anopheles in rice fields; (6) Ob-
servations on incidence of Anopheles in rice growing region:
collected in image stage 3,235, A. quadrimaculatus 57%, A.
crucians 43%; bred out 383, percentage about the same; (7)
Blood specimens examined for malaria parasites 112, positive
20, P. vivax 19, P. falciparum one.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A.A. Surgeon Wm. A. Krauss and
Microscopists Ethel Barrier and Retha Kitchens.

630 blood smears were examined for malaria parasites, of which
433 were sent in locally for diagnosis, of these 53 were posi-
tive P. vivax, 24 positive P. falciparum and three double in-
fections; 156 blood specimens were collected in Leflore County,
Mississippi, of which twelve were positive P. vivax and one
Monthly Progress Report
-2-
August 6, 1924.
positive P. falciparum; the remaining 41 slides sent in for
examination from Tennessee, Arkansas and Missouri showed six
positive P. vivax and three positive P. falciparum. One
hundred house visits were made in the study of malaria cases
under treatment.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Georgia: Personnel - Technical
Assistant Bruce Mayne.

Activities at this laboratory consisted of: observations on
Anopheles incidence, 300 imagoes collected, 40% of which were
A. quadrimaculatus, a decided increase, but A. crucians re-
mains predominant around salt marsh areas; A. crucians observ-
ed to prefer animal quarters, but several instances of house
infestation noted, especially in temporary dwellings; about
the middle of July resting Anopheles first observed in hollow
logs and tree stumps; 160 mosquitoes dissected, one A. quadri-
maculatus observed with immature oocysts on stomach wall; 101
blood specimens examined for malaria parasites, two positive
P. vivax, one positive P. falciparum.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surg.
Kennth F. Maxcy.

Dr. Maxcy detached for Brill's disease studies during greater
part of month. Prepared a paper on malaria for publication
in Florida State Medical Journal.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemio-
logist T. H. D. Griffitts and Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage.

Dr. Griffitts (Alabama), activities consisted of (1) inspection
of pond near Cowarts, Houston County, ten-acre pond impounded
last spring, pond site cleared but not maintained, fine flotage
and algae abundant, production of Anopheles quadrimaculatus pro-
fuse, Gambusia abundant, but unable to cope with mosquito pro-
duction, County Health Officer advised of situation and meas-
ures which should be enforced to control mosquito production; (2)
inspection of Golden Bridge Pond, no anopheles production, ap-
parently being controlled by oiling; (4) inspection of River
Falls Power Company Pond at Gantt's, free production of A. quad-
rimaculatus observed in the pond; (5) inspection of Mitchell's
Reservoir, Coosa River, flotage scarce, few mosquito larvae found
except in drift on Hatchett Creek; (6) inspection of Muscle
Shoals Reservoir, water being slowly impounded by the U. S. Gov-
ernment, mosquito production profuse.
Monthly Progress Report
August 6, 1924.

Mr. Gage (South Carolina), activities consisted of: contin-
uation of observations of Anopheles prevalence, increased
production observed in impounded waters with slight decrease in
production in small breeding areas in the same locality; emer-
gences from collections of larvae and pupae yielded 73% A.
crucians, 16% A. punctipennis, 11% A. quadrimaculatus; emer-
gence from collections made in larger ponds yielded 82% A.
Crucians and 18% A. quadrimaculatus; adults collected per rest-
ing place in vicinity of ponds remains about the same as for
June while the number per resting place at a greater distance
from the pond was almost double - the proportions being adjac-
ent to ponds A. crucians 87%, A. punctipennis 4%, A. quadri-
maculatus 9%, distant from ponds A. crucians 42%, A. puncti-
pennis 26%, A. quadrimaculatus 32%.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel- Assoc. San.
Eng. A. W. Fuchs.

Mr. Fuchs continued observations of Anopheles production and
physical conditions of ditches in Drainage District No. 6,
Crittenden County, Arkansas; lateral ditches have become a
series of separate pools because of continued draught; Anophe-
les production five times as prolific as in June, of 393
imagoes collected 93% were A. quadrimaculatus, 2% A. puncti-
pennis; Gambusia present in all ditches, abundant in some,
vegetation abundant; Gambusia unable to fully cope with mos-
quito production.

Cooperative Fish Studies: Mr. Samuel F. Hildebrand of the
Bureau of Fisheries continued his cooperative fish control
investigations around Augusta, Georgia. Heavy rainfalls
and abnormally high temperatures have seriously interfered
with these studies during the month.

Rural Malaria Control Investigations: Personnel - Asst. San.
Eng. J. C. Carter, A. A. Surg. C. P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng.
L. M. Fisher, Asst. San. Eng. J. G. Foster, Assoc. San. Eng.
A. W. Fuchs, Asst. San. Eng. H. N. Old, Asst. San. Eng. F. R.
Shaw and Surgeon L. L. Williams, Jr.

Mr. Carter (Alabama), activities consisted of: screen survey
continued in Houston County; shallow wells or holes dug in two
intermittent ponds and stocked with Gambusia for observation;
malaria surveys made around thirteen saw mills in Houston,
Barbour, Clarke, Escambia and Montgomery Counties; observation
made of the effect of distillate from a gas tar plant on mos-
quito larvae, Anopheles larvae killed by distillate in three
minutes; stegomyia deposited eggs in barrel two days after ap-
Monthly Progress Report
-4-
August 6, 1924.
plication of distillate.

Mr. Old (Georgia), activities consisted of: continued ob-
servations of mosquito production; 1.91 inches excess rain-
fall during month, practically all thunder showers, rapid
run-off; no great increase in potential breeding areas, no
increase observed in mosquito production; 1555 dips at 41
stations gave only 42 larvae and four pupae; enormous in-
crease in Gambusia undoubtedly responsible for the scarc-
ity of mosquito larvae, A. quadrimaculatus becoming more
prevalent though not yet predominating over A. crucians
except in one section of the County; 407 adult mosquitoes
collected from 66 locations including dwellings, outhouses
and animal sheds showed A. quadrimaculatus more abundant
in dwelling houses, A. crucians in animal sheds.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana), activities consisted of rural malaria
control studies in Tangipahoa and St. Mary's Parishes: study
of the effect of screening of rural homes being made; survey
of drainage canal at Patterson in St. Mary's Parish; 350
cisterns in Patterson stocked with Gambusia; Gambusia surviv-
ed three weeks in steel water barrel with temperature ranging
up to 100 degrees.

Dr. Coogle and Asst. San. Eng. J.G. Foster (Mississippi), act-
ivities consisted of: continuation of malaria and mosquito
study in Leflore County, Mississippi, 192 houses treated with
creosote oil during 1923 were inspected; study of the effect
of screening on malaria prevalence in group of twenty planta-
tion houses continued; collection of information relative to
malaria prevalence in the localities under observation.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina), activites consisted of: rural
malaria control investigations continued; study of fish con-
trol of mosquito production in shallow pond near Columbia
continued, star head minnows abundant in this pond, mosquito
production profuse; at Chester, S.C. where only A. punctipennis
have been observed, one female A. crucians was collected; mal-
aria survey made in Charleston County as help ionty

Monthly Progress Report
August 6, 1924.

Mr. Fuchs in addition to major drainage studies was assign-
ed to rural malaria control investigations in Gibson and
Obion Counties, Tennessee, and Dunklin and New Madrid Coun-
ties, Missouri. Mr. Fuchs visited these four counties
during July and advised the county health officers relative
to handling their malaria control problems.
Surgeon L. L. Williams (Virginia) - No report received.

Conferences and Inspections: Medical Officer in Charge
remained at field headquarters preparing annual report.

Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A. LePrince on leave, attending
International Conference on Health Problems at Jamaica.

Expenditures: During the month approximately $4,391.00
was expended from the Malaria Allotment in connection with
field investigations of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
